1.An owner or operator shall provide an executive summary that includes, without limitation, a brief description of the following:

(a)    The policies for accidental release prevention and the policies for emergency response at the facility;

Great Lakes Cheese recognizes management?s responsibility in protecting its employees, visitors, contractors and neighbors, property and the environment.  The safety and health of all personnel and the protection of the environment are important to the Company.  The control of accidents will be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the facility.

The Company will have a Plant Safety Program.  The primary objective of the Plant Safety Program is to achieve maximum efficiency and safety performance.

To accomplish the Company?s goal in preventing the accidental releases of ammonia and minimizing the impact of any release, the facility has developed (an will implement) a Program to comply with the EPA?s Risk Management Program regulation (Risk Management Program for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  Emergency Response programs have been developed as well.  The objectives of the RMP/PSM programs are to prevent the accidental releases through use of good operating procedures and mechanical integrity of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The Plant Manager is ultimately responsible for the management of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs.

(b)    The substances that are handled at the facility;

Great Lakes Cheese will operate a processing facility where raw and processed cheese will be stored in free-standing racks.  An important part of the this operation is keeping this aforementioned material cold.  For this, anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) will be used as the refrigerant.  The maximum intended inventory is 14,000 pounds.

The ammonia refrigeration system will be a closed loop system whereby liquid ammonia from the Control Pressure Receiver located in the Engine Room suppli

es the Recirculated System its refrigerant.  During cooling, the refrigerant (ammonia) is pumped with pressure through the cooler units for cooling and returns to the Accumulator in both liquid and vapor form.  The vapor is drawn into the screw compressors through the suction line where they are compressed and discharged through piping to the ammonia condenser located outside.  Forced air and recirculated water cool and condense the vapors.  From the condensers, the ammonia drain by gravity back to the Control Pressure Receiver, thus completing the loop.  Ammonia is a non-corrosive chemical; therefore, does not deteriorate the inside of vessels, line or valves provided they are carbon steel (not copper).  It also carries a small amount of oil from the compressors that would tend to further protect the inside surfaces.  All vessels containing ammonia will be ASME pressure rated at 250 psi or higher which is higher than the maximum operating pressure.  All pressure vessels will be Permitted by the State of Utah and inspected according to the State requirements.

(c)    Each worst-case release scenario and alternative release scenario, including without limitation, administrative controls and mitigation measure taken to limit the distances to the endpoint for each scenario;

The Worst-Case release scenario involves the release of 14,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia over a 10 minute period which would result due to a failure of the Control Pressure Receiver.  This quantity is considered in the event that (for some reason) the entire system charge would be ?pumped down? into the Control Pressure Receiver and the Control Pressure Receiver should rupture.  Pressure vessels are never to be filled to more than 80% or 85% or their capacity and the 14,000 pounds is based on 100% of the vessel.  Under this Worst-Case scenario and the prescribed ?stale? air and wind conditions, ammonia could travel 1.6 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.

The Wor

in the Engine Room, Penthouses and the Dock would alarm in the event of a release so that quick action could be taken to reduce the impact;

(d)    The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific steps for prevention;

The program consists of the following elements:

?    Employee Participation: The Plant Engineer and Contractor President, Engineers, pipe fitters and controls personnel have participated in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs) and in developing the Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs).  Maintenance personnel and the operators will be trained and the program will be reviewed with the operators.
?    Process Safety Information: Piping and Instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) have been developed where all ammonia vessels, lines and valves are numbered on the drawings.  All ammonia valves (except small gauge valves) are numbered with a valve tag.  Information has been collected which will enable the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the system.  The written information includes the ammonia MSDS.
?    Process Hazard Analysis: Formal studies were conducted using the What-if/Check List Technique to look at the system and identify potential hazards.  The PHAs are maintained on a computer program for easy and accurate management.  All recommendations will be addressed in a timely manner.
?    Operating Procedures: Written procedures have developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safety operate the ammonia refrigeration system.  Although the system is controlled the Frick Computer software, the system can be run ?locally? if necessary.  The system can also be accessed by modem to shut off any solenoid supply valve or other electrical components of the system.
?    Training: A training program will be developed to ensure that employees are trained in all aspects of the system and the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation fo the ammonia refrigeration system.
?    Contractors: Contractors are and will

be screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.
?    Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review will be completed prior to the startup of the system and for all new ammonia refrigeration projects involving a change to the system to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been performed, operating procedures developed, P&IDs developed, PHA completed, and construction has been completed according to the design specifications.
?    Mechanical Integrity: Annual inspections of the ammonia refrigeration system including lines and valves by a refrigeration contractor.  Pressure vessels of 5 cubic feet or more or equipment holding 120 gallons or more of ammonia will be Permitted by the State and inspected by an independent inspector (i.e., insurance carrier) every 4 years.  Any recommendation will be resolved promptly.
?    Hot Work Permits: Procedures to be followed to ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning in any area other than one designated a ?hot work?.
?    Management of Change: The procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration system are properly reviewed.
?    Incident Investigation: All incidents or ?near misses? will be investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team.
?    Compliance Audits: Audits will be conducted every three years to ascertain whether or not the program in place is working properly.

(e)    The emergency response program;

An emergency action plan has been developed for the facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia releases and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  The program has been discussed (copy provided) with the Fillmore City Fire Department.  Changes or modifications will be made if deemed necessary.

(f)    A Plan to Abate Hazards (PTAH) if the facility has a process that is subject to the tier A program or tier

B program level 2 or 3.

3.    For each recommendation made pursuant to subsections 1 and 2, the owner or operator shall provide:
(a)    A description of the hazard;
(b)    The cause of the hazard;
(c)    Consequences of the hazard;
(d)    A description of the recommendation; and
(e)    The implementation date for the recommendation.
